text: EDUARDO ROBLES, having been first duly sworn, testified through the duly sworn interpreter as follows: EXAMINATION
Would you state your complete name for the record, please.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Could you spell the middle name, please.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Okay.  Mr. Robles, my name is Frank Newton.  I represent Kuraray in this deposition and in this lawsuit that you have brought against Kuraray.  Do you understand who I am and who I represent?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Yes.  Yes, I do understand, sir.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you understand that I'm on the opposite side of this lawsuit from you and your attorney here representing you?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Have you ever given a deposition before?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Let me cover a few basic ground rules since this is -- this is your first time to be deposed.  First of all, it's important you understand that you've been placed under oath.  This is the same oath you'd be under if you were testifying in open court. Do you understand that?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: It carries with it the same pains and penalties for perjury as if you were testifying in open court. Do you understand that?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Your attorney, Mr. Garvin, may have had a chance to meet with you before the deposition and explain to you what to expect.  Let me cover a few additional ground rules.  First of all --
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: -- it's important that you give audible responses like yes, no, I don't know, as opposed to uh-huh, uh-uh, or shrugging your shoulders or nodding your head.  Okay?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: That way we will be able to get your intended testimony as opposed to me just assuming I know what you mean or intend to say.  Okay?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: So from time to time, I say, is that a "yes"? Or is that a "no"?  I'm not being rude.  I'm just making sure we have your intended testimony on the record.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Also, if you'll remember to wait until I have completed my question before you begin your answer, I'll return the courtesy and wait for you to complete your answer before I ask another question.  Okay?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: That way we're not talking over each other, and the court reporter will be able to write down accurately what your testimony is and what the questions are.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Also, if there are any questions that I ask you today that you don't understand or would like to have phrased differently or just repeated, you're certainly free to do so.  Okay?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: And since you have that opportunity, may we have this understanding that any question you answer you have understood?  Fair enough?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Have you ever given deposition or testimony of any kind in a deposition, hearing, courtroom, tribunal, anything of that sort before today?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Have you ever filed suit other than the lawsuit against Kuraray?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: How so?  What do you want me to tell you?  What happened?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  Did you file suit against somebody for something that happened to you?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Yes.  I was -- it was related to an acid burn.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when did this occur?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Did you file a Workers' Compensation claim for that?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: I don't remember.  I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say you filed suit, who did you sue?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: And what was the name of that plant?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: And where did this accident occur?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: What part of your body was burned by the acid?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: My face a little and my left leg.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who was your lawyer in that lawsuit?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Did you settle that case, or did it go to trial?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: We -- there was a settlement.  We didn't go to court.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you give a deposition before it settled?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: And have you ever filed any other lawsuits besides that one against the Rohm and Haas and this one against Kuraray?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Have you ever been sued before?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Have you ever been a witness in someone else's lawsuit?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Besides the acid burn in '91 and '92, have you ever been hurt on the job before?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: (BY MR. NEWTON)  Okay.  Other than that?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Have you ever filed a Workers' Compensation claim?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: As I said with the '91 accident, I don't remember, but since then, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you come to the United States?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Are you a US citizen, or do you have a green card to allow you to work here?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Currently now, yes, I'm a citizen.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (BY MR. NEWTON)  When did you become a citizen of the United States?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: What states have you lived in besides Texas?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Have you ever been arrested for a criminal offense?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: In this state or in any country?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: What countries have you lived in besides Mexico and the United States?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: I lived for a very short while in Canada for work, but we're talking about a few months.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many times have you worked in Canada?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: And who did you work for in Canada?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Okay.  And what was it before then?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Do you have a driver's license?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Do you have it with you?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Objection.  The witness -- the deponent will not produce his driver's license at this time.
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: What's your basis for that, Counselor?  We have gotten driver licenses for every witness here at this law firm and in this lawsuit.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: That could be produced at a later date through a request for production, but this is deposition.
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: I understand that.  I want to see his driver's license and make sure this -- this is who we're supposed to be talking to.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: We can discuss it more after a break, but at this point, I'm not going to have him produce any documents that haven't already been requested.
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: We requested his driver's license.  Yes.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: And you have a copy of it.
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: And the one that we -- the one that we have is expired; so I want to see if he has a current driver's license.  And I'm entitled to ask that. If you want to check with one of your superiors here, I certainly encourage you to do so.  But if you get in the way of the deposition of this question, seek relief.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Well, if you want to ask him if he's updated his license, feel free, Counselor.  But to ask him to produce something, that's not the purpose of a deposition.
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: Every witness has produced his driver's license.  Have you done very many of these depositions?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: That's not a logical argument, Counselor.
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: Have you done -- I've practiced 30 years.  Don't tell me how to practice law. I won't tell you how to practice medicine.  Okay?  Let's make this deal.  Have you done very many of these depositions?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Okay.  Well, this is a first time I've ever heard anybody object to someone producing their driver's license.  This is a first.  So you can take some pride in that I guess.  On what possible basis are you refusing the witness to provide to me during this deposition a copy of his driver's license so we can confirm his identity?  On what possible basis, legal or otherwise?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Because producing documents is not the purpose of a deposition.
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: It's not a document.  I'm asking him to show me his current driver's license.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: I'm asking him to show me his current driver's license.  Would you check with one of your folks on a break and see if they tell you otherwise?  Because we've gotten it from -- I mean everybody.  Mo, Benny, Ajay, everybody.  Has anybody told you different?  That you're not supposed to let the witness provide his driver's license?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Counselor, if we're done with the verbal harassment of me --
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: No one's harassing you. You're harassing me --
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: -- in getting in the way of this deposition by telling him -- or telling me he can't produce his driver's license.  That's ridiculous.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: I will check with Benny, but in my opinion is you've got his driver's license.
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: It's expired.  I want to see if his current driver's license is otherwise.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: I'm entitled to ask that and get --
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: -- how to ask questions. Don't tell on me getting how to take my deposition. You're getting in the way of this deposition, and it's -- it's ridiculous.  This is not exactly a major case.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: This is not a major issue.  We can resolve --
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: It is a major issue.  I want to see his current driver's license.  The other day we took a deposition in this building of someone who hadn't had a driver's license current for three to four years. And guess how he got to the deposition?  He drove here. So this is all relevant to our inquiries.  We are entitled to ask.  If you want to take the position that we're -- you're not somehow required -- he's not required to produce his driver's license, we'll take it up with the Court.  Is that your position?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: My position is he's not required to produce his driver's license during a deposition.
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: That's nonsense.  Do you have any basis for that other than that's what you think?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: (BY MR. NEWTON)  Do you have a current driver's license, Mr. Robles?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: When did you renew it, sir?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Let the record reflect the witness is reaching into his billfold to check his driver's license, which his attorney does not allow him to show me across the table.  Unprecedented.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: (BY MR. NEWTON)  When does it -- is that when you renewed it?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: What's the number on your driver's license before you put it away?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: And what -- what is your current address, sir?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: It's 10606 Pillot Street, P-E-L-L-O-T [sic], in Houston, Texas 77029.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long have you lived there sir?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: And is that the -- is that the address on your driver's license?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Would you hold the license up for the videographer just to show that you do have it on you? Just hold the license up.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: You're not going to allow him to hold his license up to show we have it -- he has it? Really?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: That's essentially asking him to produce it.  It's just not the --
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: Oh, my God.  Oh, my God.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: You already know that he was reading from it.
speaker: MR. GARVIN

text: Okay.  Let -- let the record -- well, reading from something.  We don't know what it was.  He got something out of his billfold and counsel will not allow us to see his driver's license under some notion that that's somehow incorrect or improper.
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: (BY MR. NEWTON)  What kind of driver's license do you have, sir?

speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: When I was on the stairs going down, I heard a noise, and I saw everybody running.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of noise did you hear?  Can you describe it for us?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: After a moment, you -- an explosion was heard.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then you said you saw people running?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: So -- so -- so, yes.  Before the explosion when the -- when the whistling was happening, I was -- to go down, I had to be on the north side, and I was facing the south side.  And it happened on the south side.  And I saw everybody run.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now you said you were coming down the stairs to go get water at the time that you heard this whistling?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: And where did you run to?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: To Gate 4, which is the muster point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you knew where the muster point was before the event occurred; is that right?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Okay.  Can you take that red pen and mark on the map where you ended up?

text: (BY MR. NEWTON)  You said you ran to the muster point.  Can you mark where you ended up when you came to a stop there on the map?  And I want you to indicate with an E letter -- capital letter E to indicate where you ended up. Have you done so?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: Is that the muster point where you were assigned?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: So where you ended up that you've marked on the map with an E was also your muster point; is that correct?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: We should have stayed on the -- on this side, on this side of the plant, on this side of the fence.  But since there was a big danger, they put us on the parking lot side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (BY MR. NEWTON)  Okay.  So my question is, where you ended up, was that different than your muster point?
speaker: MR. NEWTON

text: No.  This was the area where we should have arrived.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. NEWTON

speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. NEWTON

speaker: MR. NEWTON

speaker: MR. NEWTON
